elements.content: Four coordination polymers with lanthanide ions and the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc), {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n , [Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Tb (4)], have been synthesized by the self-assembly reaction of potassium 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylate (K3mptc) and rare earth salts in aqueous solution. The complexes were characterized by X-ray diffraction single crystal structure analysis, elemental analysis, IR, fluorescence and thermal analysis. The four coordination polymers are isotypics and crystallize in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The Ln(III) ions are coordinated by three carboxylate groups with different coordination modes and link to form an infinite two-dimensional (2D) polymer. Infinite T6(2) water tapes containing puckered-boat hexameric water rings exist in the space between the metal crystal building layers. The T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into novel 2D L6(5)14(8) water layers through (H2O)2 dimers between adjacent water tapes.
elements.clean_text: Four coordination polymers with lanthanide ions and the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc), {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n , [Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Tb (4)], have been synthesized by the self-assembly reaction of potassium 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylate (K3mptc) and rare earth salts in aqueous solution. The complexes were characterized by X-ray diffraction single crystal structure analysis, elemental analysis, IR, fluorescence and thermal analysis. The four coordination polymers are isotypics and crystallize in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The Ln(III) ions are coordinated by three carboxylate groups with different coordination modes and link to form an infinite two-dimensional (2D) polymer. Infinite T6(2) water tapes containing puckered-boat hexameric water rings exist in the space between the metal crystal building layers. The T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into novel 2D L6(5)14(8) water layers through (H2O)2 dimers between adjacent water tapes.

elements.content: Four lanthanide complexes {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n [Ln = Pr(1), Nd(2), Sm(3), Tb(4)] from the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc) are designed and synthesized. A T6(2) water tape composed of alternating up and down puckered-boat six-membered rings is formed. Notably, the infinite T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into a novel L6(5)14(8) water layer sandwiched in the space of metal crystal building layers.
elements.clean_text: Four lanthanide complexes {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  [Ln = Pr(1), Nd(2), Sm(3), Tb(4)] from the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc) are designed and synthesized. A T6(2) water tape composed of alternating up and down puckered-boat six-membered rings is formed. Notably, the infinite T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into a novel L6(5)14(8) water layer sandwiched in the space of metal crystal building layers.

elements.content: The construction of supramolecular networks based on multifunctional multidentate ligands is currently of great interest owing to their intriguing network architecture and their potential applications as functional materials. Polycarboxylic acids, pyridine-carboxylic acids, and pyrazine-carboxylic acids have proven to be good candidates for the construction of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their ability to form multiple coordination modes. Numerous coordination polymers containing pyridine di- or tricarboxylates have been reported during the past several years. Recently, the design, synthesis, and properties of supramolecular complexes containing transition ions and the novel ligand pyridine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylaic acid (H4pdtc) were investigated. In this paper, lanthanide complexes containing 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc) as the ligand are studied. The novel organic ligand, H3mptc, was designed and synthesized based on the following considerations: (1) The 6-carboxyl group of H4pdtc was changed to a methyl group which results in a lower symmetry for H3mptc. This produces different environments for the remaining three carboxyl groups which gives the ligand various coordination modes. (2) H3mptc has three carboxyl groups and one pyridine nitrogen atom. The coordination environment for each of these donor atoms is different from each other. (3) H3mptc can act as a hydrogen-bond acceptor as well as a hydrogen-bond donor and thus can generate supramolecular structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of supramolecular networks based on multifunctional multidentate ligands is currently of great interest owing to their intriguing network architecture and their potential applications as functional materials. Polycarboxylic acids, pyridine-carboxylic acids, and pyrazine-carboxylic acids have proven to be good candidates for the construction of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their ability to form multiple coordination modes. Numerous coordination polymers containing pyridine di- or tricarboxylates have been reported during the past several years. Recently, the design, synthesis, and properties of supramolecular complexes containing transition ions and the novel ligand pyridine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylaic acid (H4pdtc) were investigated. In this paper, lanthanide complexes containing 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc) as the ligand are studied. The novel organic ligand, H3mptc, was designed and synthesized based on the following considerations: (1) The 6-carboxyl group of H4pdtc was changed to a methyl group which results in a lower symmetry for H3mptc. This produces different environments for the remaining three carboxyl groups which gives the ligand various coordination modes. (2) H3mptc has three carboxyl groups and one pyridine nitrogen atom. The coordination environment for each of these donor atoms is different from each other. (3) H3mptc can act as a hydrogen-bond acceptor as well as a hydrogen-bond donor and thus can generate supramolecular structures.

elements.content: Generally, lanthanide ions coordinate much more weakly with N atoms than with O atoms, but this difference cannot be seen when N has one or two neighboring carboxylate groups in several research studies. In these cases, the N atom participates in coordination (together with the carboxylate O atoms) with bidentate or tridentate chelating mode. In this work, it is advantageous for the N atom to coordinate as a bidentate chelate together with the O atom of 6-carboxy, while only carboxylate O atoms coordinate to metal ions while the N atom does not. It is proved that lanthanide ions have a much weaker coordination capability with the N atoms than with the O atoms.
elements.clean_text: Generally, lanthanide ions coordinate much more weakly with N atoms than with O atoms, but this difference cannot be seen when N has one or two neighboring carboxylate groups in several research studies. In these cases, the N atom participates in coordination (together with the carboxylate O atoms) with bidentate or tridentate chelating mode. In this work, it is advantageous for the N atom to coordinate as a bidentate chelate together with the O atom of 6-carboxy, while only carboxylate O atoms coordinate to metal ions while the N atom does not. It is proved that lanthanide ions have a much weaker coordination capability with the N atoms than with the O atoms.

elements.content: It is universally accepted that water is the most essential and important compound for living beings. It exhibits a fascinating array of structures and modes not only in nature but also in many biological and chemical systems. For example, isolated water clusters, chains, and sheets have been found in steam, liquid water, and ice. Therefore, the investigation and identification of different forms of water clusters have attracted much interest. Although numerous studies on water clusters, such as (H2O) n (n = 2−11, n ≠ 5), water chains/tapes, and layers, have been reported, water is still not a fully understood liquid.
elements.clean_text: It is universally accepted that water is the most essential and important compound for living beings. It exhibits a fascinating array of structures and modes not only in nature but also in many biological and chemical systems. For example, isolated water clusters, chains, and sheets have been found in steam, liquid water, and ice. Therefore, the investigation and identification of different forms of water clusters have attracted much interest. Although numerous studies on water clusters, such as (H2O) n  (n = 2-11, n ≠ 5), water chains/tapes, and layers, have been reported, water is still not a fully understood liquid.

elements.content: Here, we report an infinite T6(2) water tape, which contains puckered-boat hexameric water rings. The water tapes connect to form a two-dimensional (2D) water layer L6(5)14(8) stabilized in 2D lanthanide complexes. The water layer motif composed of 6-membered and 14-membered rings has not been seen before and is completely new to the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). In this work, four coordination polymers with H3mptc and lanthanide ions, {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n [Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Tb (4)], were synthesized and characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction, elemental analysis, IR, fluorescence and thermal analysis. The terbium complex shows a strong fluorescent emission.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report an infinite T6(2) water tape, which contains puckered-boat hexameric water rings. The water tapes connect to form a two-dimensional (2D) water layer L6(5)14(8) stabilized in 2D lanthanide complexes. The water layer motif composed of 6-membered and 14-membered rings has not been seen before and is completely new to the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). In this work, four coordination polymers with H3mptc and lanthanide ions, {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  [Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Tb (4)], were synthesized and characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction, elemental analysis, IR, fluorescence and thermal analysis. The terbium complex shows a strong fluorescent emission.

elements.content: The rare earth salts were obtained by reacting acetic acid and hydrochloric acid with the corresponding lanthanide oxide. The potassium 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylate (K3mptc) was prepared from 2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate using potassium permanganate as the oxidant. Other chemicals were reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 with a Bruker TENOR 27 spectrophotometer using a KBr pellet. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments were performed on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a Cary Eclipse EL06063917 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The rare earth salts were obtained by reacting acetic acid and hydrochloric acid with the corresponding lanthanide oxide. The potassium 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylate (K3mptc) was prepared from 2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate using potassium permanganate as the oxidant. Other chemicals were reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 with a Bruker TENOR 27 spectrophotometer using a KBr pellet. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments were performed on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a Cary Eclipse EL06063917 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.

elements.content: {[Pr(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (1). A mixture of Pr(CH3COO)3·6H2O (0.0625 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Light green crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for four weeks. Yield 62% based on Pr. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.45; H, 3.52; N, 2.79%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Pr (fw = 489.15): C, 22.10; H, 3.71; N, 2.86%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3419.3s, 1594.9vs, 1429.1s, 1367.4s, 1151.4 m, 806.1 m.
elements.clean_text:
Preparations

{[Pr(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  (1). A mixture of Pr(CH3COO)3⋅6H2O (0.0625 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol⋅L-1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Light green crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for four weeks. Yield 62% based on Pr. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.45; H, 3.52; N, 2.79%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Pr (fw = 489.15): C, 22.10; H, 3.71; N, 2.86%. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3419.3s, 1594.9vs, 1429.1s, 1367.4s, 1151.4 m, 806.1 m.

elements.content: {[Nd(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (2). A mixture of Nd(CH3COO)3·6H2O (0.0630 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 1.5 h and then filtered. Light purple crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for six weeks. Yield 65% based on Nd. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.04; H, 3.47; N, 2.53%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Nd (fw = 492.48) C, 21.95; H, 3.68; N, 2.84%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3321.0vs, 1596.8vs, 1430.9s, 1369.3s, 1145.5 m, 806.1 m, 649.9 m. Crystals of 2 were also obtained under hydrothermal conditions: the same mixture as above was placed in a 25 mL Teflon high temperature kettle, under autogenous pressure at 140 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 2 °C·h−1 and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C·h−1.
elements.clean_text: {[Nd(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  (2). A mixture of Nd(CH3COO)3⋅6H2O (0.0630 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol⋅L-1) was stirred at room temperature for 1.5 h and then filtered. Light purple crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for six weeks. Yield 65% based on Nd. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.04; H, 3.47; N, 2.53%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Nd (fw = 492.48) C, 21.95; H, 3.68; N, 2.84%. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3321.0vs, 1596.8vs, 1430.9s, 1369.3s, 1145.5 m, 806.1 m, 649.9 m. Crystals of 2 were also obtained under hydrothermal conditions: the same mixture as above was placed in a 25 mL Teflon high temperature kettle, under autogenous pressure at 140 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 2 °C⋅h-1 and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C⋅h-1.

elements.content: {[Sm(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (3). A mixture of SmCl3·6H2O (0.0547 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and an aqueous HCl solution (1.5 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Light yellow crystals of 3 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 63% based on Sm for 3. Elemental analysis, found: C, 21.82; H, 3.46; N, 2.62%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Sm (fw = 498.59) C, 21.68; H, 3.64; N, 2.81%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3349.9vs, 1600.7vs, 1429.1s, 1386.6s, 1151.3 m, 808.1 m, 649.9 m.

Light yellow crystals of 3 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 63% based on Sm for 3. elements.content: {[Tb(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (4). A mixture of TbCl3·6H2O (0.0559 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and an aqueous HCl solution (1.5 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Colorless crystals of 4 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 59% based on Tb for 4. Elemental analysis, found: C, 21.15; H, 3.46; N, 2.82%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Tb (fw = 507.16) C, 21.31; H, 3.58; N, 2.76%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3349.0vs, 1602.4vs, 1468.1s, 1434.3s, 1388.1s, 1152.5 m, 808.8 m, 657.6 m.

A mixture of TbCl3⋅6H2O (0.0559 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and an aqueous HCl solution (1.5 mL, 0.1 mol⋅L-1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Colorless crystals of 4 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 59% based on Tb for 4. Elemental analysis, found: C, 21.15; H, 3.46; N, 2.82%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Tb (fw = 507.16) C, 21.31; H, 3.58; N, 2.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3349.0vs, 1602.4vs, 1468.1s, 1434.3s, 1388.1s, 1152.5 m, 808.8 m, 657.6 m.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray data of 1, 2, and 4 were collected on a computer-controlled Rigaku Saturn diffractometer, equipped with confocal monochromatized Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073 Å using the ω-scan technique. Single crystal X-ray data of 3 were collected with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area detector diffractometer, equipped with confocal monochromatized Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71070 Å using the ω−φ scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

Single crystal X-ray data of 1, 2, and 4 were collected on a computer-controlled Rigaku Saturn diffractometer, equipped with confocal monochromatized Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073 Å using the ω-scan technique. Single crystal X-ray data of 3 were collected with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area detector diffractometer, equipped with confocal monochromatized Mo Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71070 Å using the ω-φ scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters are listed in Table .

All four complexes are stable in air and 2 is especially stable since it can be obtained from reactions at both room temperature and hydrothermal conditions indicating its higher thermal stability. In the IR spectra, two strong absorption bands were observed at 1600 to 1594 cm−1 and 1388 to 1367 cm−1 corresponding to the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching vibrations of carboxyl groups, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

All four complexes are stable in air and 2 is especially stable since it can be obtained from reactions at both room temperature and hydrothermal conditions indicating its higher thermal stability. In the IR spectra, two strong absorption bands were observed at 1600 to 1594 cm-1 and 1388 to 1367 cm-1 corresponding to the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching vibrations of carboxyl groups, respectively.

elements.content: Complexes 1−4 are isotypics and crystallize in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The coordination environments of Ln(III) and mptc are shown in Figure . The Ln(III) ion is eight coordinated and adopts a square antiprismatic geometry. The Ln(III) ion is coordinated by four water molecules (O7, O8, O9, and O10) and three mptc ligands with bidentate (O4 and O5) and monodentate (O1 or O6) modes.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analyses of {[Ln(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  [Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Tb (4)]

Complexes 1-4 are isotypics and crystallize in the monoclinic system with the P21/n space group. The coordination environments of Ln(III) and mptc are shown in Figure . The Ln(III) ion is eight coordinated and adopts a square antiprismatic geometry. The Ln(III) ion is coordinated by four water molecules (O7, O8, O9, and O10) and three mptc ligands with bidentate (O4 and O5) and monodentate (O1 or O6) modes.

elements.content: All the carboxyl groups of the ligand are deprotonated, and each mptc bridges three Ln(III) ions through three carboxylate groups. The N atom in the pyridine ring of the mptc does not coordinate with any Ln(III) ion, which is different from previously reported complexes, in which the ring N and the carboxyl O atoms participate in coordination usually through a multidentate chelating mode. Here, only O atoms participate in coordination. For the four complexes, the average bond lengths are 2.458, 2.445, 2.413, and 2.379 Å for Pr−O, Nd−O, Sm−O, and Tb−O, respectively. It decreases sequentially because of the lanthanide contraction effect. The bond angles of O−Ln−O range between 68° and 148°. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−4 are shown in the .
elements.clean_text: All the carboxyl groups of the ligand are deprotonated, and each mptc bridges three Ln(III) ions through three carboxylate groups. The N atom in the pyridine ring of the mptc does not coordinate with any Ln(III) ion, which is different from previously reported complexes, in which the ring N and the carboxyl O atoms participate in coordination usually through a multidentate chelating mode. Here, only O atoms participate in coordination. For the four complexes, the average bond lengths are 2.458, 2.445, 2.413, and 2.379 Å for Pr-O, Nd-O, Sm-O, and Tb-O, respectively. It decreases sequentially because of the lanthanide contraction effect. The bond angles of O-Ln-O range between 68° and 148°. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1-4 are shown in the .

elements.content:
The Ln(III) ions also act as nodes to connect the mptc ligands to form an infinite 2D grid motif with a parallelogram unit as the building block (Figure ).

The water molecules in the interlayer space are linked by hydrogen bonds to form T6(2) water tapes along the b-axis in 1−4 (Figure ). The water tape contains six-membered rings (O11, O12, O11, O12, O13, and O9) which share one edge (O11, O12) to form an extended tape. In addition, in the water tape, every six-membered ring has hydrogen-bonding interactions with two water monomers (O8 and O10) through O13 (Figure a). The six-membered rings of the water tape have 21 screw symmetry axis along the b-axis. (Figure b). This pattern has never been reported before. The average O···O distances of the cyclic hexamers are 2.878, 2.882, 2.886, and 2.888 Å for 1 to 4, respectively. These distances are slightly longer than the corresponding values in ice I h (2.759 Å) and liquid water (2.854 Å), as well as in the ice II phase (2.77−2.84 Å). However, they are shorter than those observed in the planar ring water hexamer (2.905 Å). The O···O···O angles in the hexamers are 112.06, 112.10, 112.02, and 112.28° for 1−4, respectively. These are comparable to the value of 109.3° for hexagonal ice. The hydrogen bond data are given in the .
elements.clean_text:
The Ln(III) ions also act as nodes to connect the mptc ligands to form an infinite 2D grid motif with a parallelogram unit as the building block (Figure ).

The water molecules in the interlayer space are linked by hydrogen bonds to form T6(2) water tapes along the b-axis in 1-4 (Figure ). The water tape contains six-membered rings (O11, O12, O11, O12, O13, and O9) which share one edge (O11, O12) to form an extended tape. In addition, in the water tape, every six-membered ring has hydrogen-bonding interactions with two water monomers (O8 and O10) through O13 (Figure a). The six-membered rings of the water tape have 21 screw symmetry axis along the b-axis. (Figure b). This pattern has never been reported before. The average O⋅⋅⋅O distances of the cyclic hexamers are 2.878, 2.882, 2.886, and 2.888 Å for 1 to 4, respectively. These distances are slightly longer than the corresponding values in ice I h (2.759 Å) and liquid water (2.854 Å), as well as in the ice II phase (2.77-2.84 Å). However, they are shorter than those observed in the planar ring water hexamer (2.905 Å). The O⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅O angles in the hexamers are 112.06, 112.10, 112.02, and 112.28° for 1-4, respectively. These are comparable to the value of 109.3° for hexagonal ice. The hydrogen bond data are given in the .

elements.content: The coordination environment of the Ln(III) ion with mptc and the square antiprismatic coordination geometry of the Ln(III) ion.
elements.clean_text: 1  The coordination environment of the Ln(III) ion with mptc and the square antiprismatic coordination geometry of the Ln(III) ion.

elements.content: View of the 2D grid motif formed from parallelogram units as the building block in 1−4.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the 2D grid motif formed from parallelogram units as the building block in 1-4.

elements.content: (a) The T6(2) water tape; (b) the alternating up and down puckered-boat motif of complexes 1−4, O8, O10, and H atoms are not shown for clarity. The symmetry code: a, 1.5 − x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 − z; b, 0.5 + x, 0.5 − y, −0.5 + z; c, x, −1 + y, z; d, 1.5 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z; e, 1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z; f, 0.5 + x, 1.5 − y, −0.5 + z.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The T6(2) water tape; (b) the alternating up and down puckered-boat motif of complexes 1-4, O8, O10, and H atoms are not shown for clarity. The symmetry code: a, 1.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; b, 0.5 + x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + z; c, x, -1 + y, z; d, 1.5 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; e, 1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; f, 0.5 + x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z.

elements.content: The water tapes link themselves to form L6(5)14(8) water layers in 1−4. Between adjacent water tapes, every two O10 water molecules act as donor and acceptor to connect themselves into dimers. The dimers then act as connectors to link the tapes to form an infinite 2D water layer in the ab plane (Figure a). Thus, the water layer contains 6-membered and 14-membered rings. The dimers (O10, O10g) belong to the 14-membered rings. Furthermore, the water monomer O8g is a dangling water molecule bonded to O13 and is part of the 14-membered rings.
elements.clean_text: The water tapes link themselves to form L6(5)14(8) water layers in 1-4. Between adjacent water tapes, every two O10 water molecules act as donor and acceptor to connect themselves into dimers. The dimers then act as connectors to link the tapes to form an infinite 2D water layer in the ab plane (Figure a). Thus, the water layer contains 6-membered and 14-membered rings. The dimers (O10, O10g) belong to the 14-membered rings. Furthermore, the water monomer O8g is a dangling water molecule bonded to O13 and is part of the 14-membered rings.

elements.content: The coordinated water (O7) does not participate in the water layer but forms hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atoms of mptc. Thus, the whole intricate hydrogen-bond network involving the carboxylate oxygen atoms, the ring N atoms, and the water molecules ensures the structure rigid and reinforces the stability between the water layer and the complex network.
elements.clean_text: The coordinated water (O7) does not participate in the water layer but forms hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atoms of mptc. Thus, the whole intricate hydrogen-bond network involving the carboxylate oxygen atoms, the ring N atoms, and the water molecules ensures the structure rigid and reinforces the stability between the water layer and the complex network.

elements.content: This structure was compared with other structures that contain water layers containing six-membered rings as their basic unit. In [Cu(Hmal)(4pds)]·6H2O, the hexameric water clusters are only in boat conformations and form a 2D water network that contains holes. The metalloorganic host is interspersed within the holes. In another report from Ramanan et al., all hexamers are in distorted chair confirmations, and these water layers are sandwiched between the long fibers of 2,3-phenazinediamine tetrahydrate. All the crystal structures containing 2D water layers reveal that formation of 2D water layers is a combination of many interactions along with crystal packing effects. Here, in order to provide a stable structure, the water layer geometry exactly matches the host structure, so when viewed along the b-axis, the wavelike water layer sandwiched in the space of the wavelike metal crystal building layers is seen (Figure b). This new water phase may provide insight into hydrogen-bonding motifs and enhance the understanding of the 2D structural aspects of water.
elements.clean_text: This structure was compared with other structures that contain water layers containing six-membered rings as their basic unit. In [Cu(Hmal)(4pds)]⋅6H2O, the hexameric water clusters are only in boat conformations and form a 2D water network that contains holes. The metalloorganic host is interspersed within the holes. In another report from Ramanan et al., all hexamers are in distorted chair confirmations, and these water layers are sandwiched between the long fibers of 2,3-phenazinediamine tetrahydrate. All the crystal structures containing 2D water layers reveal that formation of 2D water layers is a combination of many interactions along with crystal packing effects. Here, in order to provide a stable structure, the water layer geometry exactly matches the host structure, so when viewed along the b-axis, the wavelike water layer sandwiched in the space of the wavelike metal crystal building layers is seen (Figure b). This new water phase may provide insight into hydrogen-bonding motifs and enhance the understanding of the 2D structural aspects of water.

elements.content: (a) The 2D L6(5)14(8) water layer in 1−4; (b) view showing the interactions of the water layers and the complex. The symmetry code: a, 1.5 − x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 − z; d, 1.5 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z; e, 1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z; g, 1 − x, 2 − y, 1 − z.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses were carried out for polycrystalline samples 1−4 in the temperature range of 30−700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 under a nitrogen atmosphere with a sweeping gas flow rate of 30 mL·min−1 and a shield gas flow rate of 20 mL·min−1. The TG and DSC curves of 1−4 are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
TGA

Thermal gravimetric analyses were carried out for polycrystalline samples 1-4 in the temperature range of 30-700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere with a sweeping gas flow rate of 30 mL⋅min-1 and a shield gas flow rate of 20 mL⋅min-1. The TG and DSC curves of 1-4 are shown in Figure .

elements.content: The first weight loss for complexes 1−4 in the temperature range of 80−220 °C are at 25.0, 23.5, 23.4, and 22.6%, respectively, and are due to the loss of three uncoordinated and four coordinated water molecules (calcd. 25.7, 25.5, 25.2, 24.8% for 1−4, respectively). The endothermic peaks at about 130 °C in the DSC curves correspond to consume energy values of 539.3, 545.4, 610.1, 627.4 J/g for 1−4, respectively. The peaks correspond to the loss of water molecules. In the temperature range of 220−480 °C, there are no weight changes in the TG curves. The second weight loss above 480 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the complexes.
elements.clean_text: The first weight loss for complexes 1-4 in the temperature range of 80-220 °C are at 25.0, 23.5, 23.4, and 22.6%, respectively, and are due to the loss of three uncoordinated and four coordinated water molecules (calcd. 25.7, 25.5, 25.2, 24.8% for 1-4, respectively). The endothermic peaks at about 130 °C in the DSC curves correspond to consume energy values of 539.3, 545.4, 610.1, 627.4 J/g for 1-4, respectively. The peaks correspond to the loss of water molecules. In the temperature range of 220-480 °C, there are no weight changes in the TG curves. The second weight loss above 480 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the complexes.

elements.content: TG and DSC curves of 1−4.
elements.clean_text: 5  TG and DSC curves of 1-4.

elements.content: The photoluminescent spectrum for complex 4 in aqueous solution was measured in the visible region at an excitation wavelength of 284 nm (Figure ). The fluorescent emission consists of four main peaks at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 584 nm (5D4 → 7F4) and 621 nm (5D4 → 7F3). The emission band at 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5) is obviously stronger than the others, which is consistent with solid-state photoluminescent data in the literature. Complex 4 shows a strong photoluminescence which is probably due to the rich uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules which hold a perfect stiff crystallinity and thus greatly enhance the radiation process, just as what is observed in the literature. Furthermore, for complex 4, the luminescence peaks do not shift whether the complexes are in aqueous solution or in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

The photoluminescent spectrum for complex 4 in aqueous solution was measured in the visible region at an excitation wavelength of 284 nm (Figure ). The fluorescent emission consists of four main peaks at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 584 nm (5D4 → 7F4) and 621 nm (5D4 → 7F3). The emission band at 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5) is obviously stronger than the others, which is consistent with solid-state photoluminescent data in the literature. Complex 4 shows a strong photoluminescence which is probably due to the rich uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules which hold a perfect stiff crystallinity and thus greatly enhance the radiation process, just as what is observed in the literature. Furthermore, for complex 4, the luminescence peaks do not shift whether the complexes are in aqueous solution or in the solid state.

elements.content: Photoluminescent spectrum for {[Tb(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (4) in aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: 6  Photoluminescent spectrum for {[Tb(mptc)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O} n  (4) in aqueous solution.

elements.content: In summary, four 2D lanthanide coordination polymers with a grid motif are the first examples from the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc). The ligand adopts a tetradentate chelate mode and coordinates to three Ln(III) ions. Only the O atoms participate in coordination. The N atom does not coordinate which indicates that lanthanide atoms coordinate with O atoms much more easily than with N atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, four 2D lanthanide coordination polymers with a grid motif are the first examples from the novel ligand 6-methyl-2,3,5-pyridinetricarboxylic acid (H3mptc). The ligand adopts a tetradentate chelate mode and coordinates to three Ln(III) ions. Only the O atoms participate in coordination. The N atom does not coordinate which indicates that lanthanide atoms coordinate with O atoms much more easily than with N atoms.

elements.content: In addition, a T6(2) water tape composed of alternating up and down puckered-boat six-membered rings is formed in the four complexes. Notably, the infinite T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into a novel L6(5)14(8) water layer through (H2O)2 dimers between the adjacent tapes. Thus, the larger puckered 14-membered water rings are formed. This association of puckered cyclic 14-membered and 6-membered water rings has not been predicted theoretically nor previously reported experimentally. Furthermore, the polymer of Tb(III) shows strong photoluminescence in the visible region.
elements.clean_text: In addition, a T6(2) water tape composed of alternating up and down puckered-boat six-membered rings is formed in the four complexes. Notably, the infinite T6(2) water tapes self-assemble into a novel L6(5)14(8) water layer through (H2O)2 dimers between the adjacent tapes. Thus, the larger puckered 14-membered water rings are formed. This association of puckered cyclic 14-membered and 6-membered water rings has not been predicted theoretically nor previously reported experimentally. Furthermore, the polymer of Tb(III) shows strong photoluminescence in the visible region.

cln_elements.content:
{[Pr(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (1). A mixture of Pr(CH3COO)3·6H2O (0.0625 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Light green crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for four weeks. Yield 62% based on Pr. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.45; H, 3.52; N, 2.79%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Pr (fw = 489.15): C, 22.10; H, 3.71; N, 2.86%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3419.3s, 1594.9vs, 1429.1s, 1367.4s, 1151.4 m, 806.1 m.

{[Nd(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (2). A mixture of Nd(CH3COO)3·6H2O (0.0630 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL) and an aqueous acetic acid solution (2 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 1.5 h and then filtered. Light purple crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for six weeks. Yield 65% based on Nd. Elemental analysis, found: C, 22.04; H, 3.47; N, 2.53%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Nd (fw = 492.48) C, 21.95; H, 3.68; N, 2.84%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3321.0vs, 1596.8vs, 1430.9s, 1369.3s, 1145.5 m, 806.1 m, 649.9 m. Crystals of 2 were also obtained under hydrothermal conditions: the same mixture as above was placed in a 25 mL Teflon high temperature kettle, under autogenous pressure at 140 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 2 °C·h−1 and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C·h−1.

{[Sm(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (3). A mixture of SmCl3·6H2O (0.0547 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and an aqueous HCl solution (1.5 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Light yellow crystals of 3 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 63% based on Sm for 3. Elemental analysis, found: C, 21.82; H, 3.46; N, 2.62%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Sm (fw = 498.59) C, 21.68; H, 3.64; N, 2.81%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3349.9vs, 1600.7vs, 1429.1s, 1386.6s, 1151.3 m, 808.1 m, 649.9 m.

{[Tb(mptc)(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (4). A mixture of TbCl3·6H2O (0.0559 g, 0.15 mmol), K3mptc (0.0508 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and an aqueous HCl solution (1.5 mL, 0.1 mol·L−1) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then filtered. Colorless crystals of 4 were obtained after the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for about six weeks. Yield 59% based on Tb for 4. Elemental analysis, found: C, 21.15; H, 3.46; N, 2.82%; calcd. for C9H18 NO13Tb (fw = 507.16) C, 21.31; H, 3.58; N, 2.76%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3349.0vs, 1602.4vs, 1468.1s, 1434.3s, 1388.1s, 1152.5 m, 808.8 m, 657.6 m.

cln_elements.content:
The first weight loss for complexes 1−4 in the temperature range of 80−220 °C are at 25.0, 23.5, 23.4, and 22.6%, respectively, and are due to the loss of three uncoordinated and four coordinated water molecules (calcd. 25.7, 25.5, 25.2, 24.8% for 1−4, respectively). The endothermic peaks at about 130 °C in the DSC curves correspond to consume energy values of 539.3, 545.4, 610.1, 627.4 J/g for 1−4, respectively. The peaks correspond to the loss of water molecules. In the temperature range of 220−480 °C, there are no weight changes in the TG curves. The second weight loss above 480 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the complexes.

Fluorescent Properties

The photoluminescent spectrum for complex 4 in aqueous solution was measured in the visible region at an excitation wavelength of 284 nm (Figure ). The fluorescent emission consists of four main peaks at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 584 nm (5D4 → 7F4) and 621 nm (5D4 → 7F3). The emission band at 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5) is obviously stronger than the others, which is consistent with solid-state photoluminescent data in the literature. Complex 4 shows a strong photoluminescence which is probably due to the rich uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules which hold a perfect stiff crystallinity and thus greatly enhance the radiation process, just as what is observed in the literature. Furthermore, for complex 4, the luminescence peaks do not shift whether the complexes are in aqueous solution or in the solid state.

The endothermic peaks at about 130 °C in the DSC curves correspond to consume energy values of 539.3, 545.4, 610.1, 627.4 J/g for 1-4, respectively. The peaks correspond to the loss of water molecules. In the temperature range of 220-480 °C, there are no weight changes in the TG curves. The second weight loss above 480 °C corresponds to the decomposition of the complexes.

Fluorescent Properties

The photoluminescent spectrum for complex 4 in aqueous solution was measured in the visible region at an excitation wavelength of 284 nm (Figure ). The fluorescent emission consists of four main peaks at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 584 nm (5D4 → 7F4) and 621 nm (5D4 → 7F3). The emission band at 545 nm (5D4 → 7F5) is obviously stronger than the others, which is consistent with solid-state photoluminescent data in the literature. Complex 4 shows a strong photoluminescence which is probably due to the rich uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules which hold a perfect stiff crystallinity and thus greatly enhance the radiation process, just as what is observed in the literature. Furthermore, for complex 4, the luminescence peaks do not shift whether the complexes are in aqueous solution or in the solid state.

metadata.title: Formation of the Water Layer in Lanthanide Coordination Polymers with 6-Methyl-2,3,5-Pyridinetricarboxylate as a Novel Bridging Ligand
